user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_get_free:
```c
size_t
MHD_pool_get_free (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
#ifdef MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE
  if ((pool->end - pool->pos) <= _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE)
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_ASAN_POISON_ACTIVE */
  return (pool->end - pool->pos) - _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_get_free:
struct MemoryPool
{

  /**
   * Pointer to the pool's memory
   */
  uint8_t *memory;

  /**
   * Size of the pool.
   */
  size_t size;

  /**
   * Offset of the first unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t pos;

  /**
   * Offset of the byte after the last unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t end;

  /**
   * 'false' if pool was malloc'ed, 'true' if mmapped (VirtualAlloc'ed for W32).
   */
  bool is_mmap;
}
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n) (((n)+(ALIGN_SIZE-1))/(ALIGN_SIZE)*(ALIGN_SIZE))
...
#define _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:

- No compiler-specific keywords or built-ins are used (no __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, __thread, typeof, typeof-like GCC extensions, or other vendor intrinsics).
- No statement-expression GCC extension ({ ... }) or nested functions are present.
- No inline assembly, naked functions, or pragma/vendor-specific directives appear (only standard #ifdef/#endif are used).
- All types used (size_t, uint8_t, bool) are standard C types or standard-library typedefs, not compiler extensions.
- Macros (ROUND_TO_ALIGN, _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE, mhd_assert) are ordinary preprocessor constructs, not language extensions.

Note: Identifier _MHD_RED_ZONE_SIZE begins with an underscore and an uppercase letter; this is in the implementation-reserved namespace and may be a portability/style concern but is not a compiler language extension per se, so it is not reported under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
